trans-unit.source: Naming and Referencing Containers, Blobs, and Metadata
trans-unit.target: Naming and Referencing Containers, Blobs, and Metadata

trans-unit.source: This topic describes naming and referring to containers, blobs, metadata, and snapshots.
trans-unit.target: This topic describes naming and referring to containers, blobs, metadata, and snapshots.

trans-unit.source: A storage account can contain zero or more containers.
trans-unit.target: A storage account can contain zero or more containers.

trans-unit.source: A container contains properties, metadata, and zero or more blobs.
trans-unit.target: A container contains properties, metadata, and zero or more blobs.

trans-unit.source: A blob is any single entity comprised of binary data, properties, and metadata.
trans-unit.target: A blob is any single entity comprised of binary data, properties, and metadata.

trans-unit.source: Resource Names
trans-unit.target: Resource Names

trans-unit.source: The URI to reference a container or a blob must be unique.
trans-unit.target: The URI to reference a container or a blob must be unique.

trans-unit.source: Because every account name is unique, two accounts can have containers with the same name.
trans-unit.target: Because every account name is unique, two accounts can have containers with the same name.

trans-unit.source: However, within a given storage account, every container must have a unique name.
trans-unit.target: However, within a given storage account, every container must have a unique name.

trans-unit.source: Every blob within a given container must also have a unique name within that container.
trans-unit.target: Every blob within a given container must also have a unique name within that container.

trans-unit.source: If you attempt to create a container or blob with a name that violates naming rules, the request will fail with status code 400 (Bad Request).
trans-unit.target: If you attempt to create a container or blob with a name that violates naming rules, the request will fail with status code 400 (Bad Request).

trans-unit.source: Blob and container names are passed to the Blob service within a URL.
trans-unit.target: Blob and container names are passed to the Blob service within a URL.

trans-unit.source: Certain characters must be percent-encoded to appear in a URL, using UTF-8 (preferred) or MBCS.
trans-unit.target: Certain characters must be percent-encoded to appear in a URL, using UTF-8 (preferred) or MBCS.

trans-unit.source: This encoding occurs automatically when you use the Azure .NET Libraries or construct a <codeEntityReference autoUpgrade="true" qualifyHint="false">T:System.Uri</codeEntityReference> object that includes a blob or container name.
trans-unit.target: This encoding occurs automatically when you use the Azure .NET Libraries or construct a <codeEntityReference autoUpgrade="true" qualifyHint="false">T:System.Uri</codeEntityReference> object that includes a blob or container name.

trans-unit.source: However, there are certain characters that are not valid in URL paths even when encoded.
trans-unit.target: However, there are certain characters that are not valid in URL paths even when encoded.

trans-unit.source: These characters cannot appear in blob or container names.
trans-unit.target: These characters cannot appear in blob or container names.

trans-unit.source: Code points like \uE000, while valid in NTFS filenames, are not valid Unicode characters, so they cannot be used.
trans-unit.target: Code points like \uE000, while valid in NTFS filenames, are not valid Unicode characters, so they cannot be used.

trans-unit.source: In addition, some ASCII or Unicode characters, like control characters (0x00 to 0x1F, \u0081, etc.), are also not allowed.
trans-unit.target: In addition, some ASCII or Unicode characters, like control characters (0x00 to 0x1F, \u0081, etc.), are also not allowed.

trans-unit.source: For rules governing Unicode strings in HTTP/1.1 see:
trans-unit.target: For rules governing Unicode strings in HTTP/1.1 see:

trans-unit.source: RFC 2616, Section 2.2: Basic Rules
trans-unit.target: RFC 2616, Section 2.2: Basic Rules

trans-unit.source: RFC 3987
trans-unit.target: RFC 3987

trans-unit.source: Container Names
trans-unit.target: Container Names

trans-unit.source: A container name must be a valid DNS name, conforming to the following naming rules:
trans-unit.target: A container name must be a valid DNS name, conforming to the following naming rules:

trans-unit.source: Container names must start with a letter or number, and can contain only letters, numbers, and the dash (-) character.
trans-unit.target: Container names must start with a letter or number, and can contain only letters, numbers, and the dash (-) character.

trans-unit.source: Every dash (-) character must be immediately preceded and followed by a letter or number; consecutive dashes are not permitted in container names.
trans-unit.target: Every dash (-) character must be immediately preceded and followed by a letter or number; consecutive dashes are not permitted in container names.

trans-unit.source: All letters in a container name must be lowercase.
trans-unit.target: All letters in a container name must be lowercase.

trans-unit.source: Container names must be from 3 through 63 characters long.
trans-unit.target: Container names must be from 3 through 63 characters long.

trans-unit.source: Blob Names
trans-unit.target: Blob Names

trans-unit.source: A blob name must conforming to the following naming rules:
trans-unit.target: A blob name must conforming to the following naming rules:

trans-unit.source: A blob name can contain any combination of characters.
trans-unit.target: A blob name can contain any combination of characters.

trans-unit.source: A blob name must be at least one character long and cannot be more than 1,024 characters long.
trans-unit.target: A blob name must be at least one character long and cannot be more than 1,024 characters long.

trans-unit.source: Blob names are case-sensitive.
trans-unit.target: Blob names are case-sensitive.

trans-unit.source: Reserved URL characters must be properly escaped.
trans-unit.target: Reserved URL characters must be properly escaped.

trans-unit.source: The number of path segments comprising the blob name cannot exceed 254.
trans-unit.target: The number of path segments comprising the blob name cannot exceed 254.

trans-unit.source: A path segment is the string between consecutive delimiter characters (<legacyItalic>e.g.</legacyItalic>, the forward slash '/') that corresponds to the name of a virtual directory.
trans-unit.target: A path segment is the string between consecutive delimiter characters (<legacyItalic>e.g.</legacyItalic>, the forward slash '/') that corresponds to the name of a virtual directory.

trans-unit.source: Avoid blob names that end with a dot (.), a forward slash (/), or a sequence or combination of the two.
trans-unit.target: Avoid blob names that end with a dot (.), a forward slash (/), or a sequence or combination of the two.

trans-unit.source: The Blob service is based on a flat storage scheme, not a hierarchical scheme.
trans-unit.target: The Blob service is based on a flat storage scheme, not a hierarchical scheme.

trans-unit.source: However, you may specify a character or string delimiter within a blob name to create a virtual hierarchy.
trans-unit.target: However, you may specify a character or string delimiter within a blob name to create a virtual hierarchy.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following list shows valid and unique blob names.
trans-unit.target: For example, the following list shows valid and unique blob names.

trans-unit.source: Notice that a string can be valid as both a blob name and as a virtual directory name in the same container:
trans-unit.target: Notice that a string can be valid as both a blob name and as a virtual directory name in the same container:

trans-unit.source: /a
trans-unit.target: /a

trans-unit.source: /a.txt
trans-unit.target: /a.txt

trans-unit.source: /a/b
trans-unit.target: /a/b

trans-unit.source: /a/b.txt
trans-unit.target: /a/b.txt

trans-unit.source: You can take advantage of the delimiter character when enumerating blobs.
trans-unit.target: You can take advantage of the delimiter character when enumerating blobs.

trans-unit.source: Metadata Names
trans-unit.target: Metadata Names

trans-unit.source: Metadata for a container or blob resource is stored as name-value pairs associated with the resource.
trans-unit.target: Metadata for a container or blob resource is stored as name-value pairs associated with the resource.

trans-unit.source: Metadata names must adhere to the naming rules for <externalLink><linkText>C# identifiers</linkText><linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/aa664670(VS.71).aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: Metadata names must adhere to the naming rules for <externalLink><linkText>C# identifiers</linkText><linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/aa664670(VS.71).aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: Note that metadata names preserve the case with which they were created, but are case-insensitive when set or read.
trans-unit.target: Note that metadata names preserve the case with which they were created, but are case-insensitive when set or read.

trans-unit.source: If two or more metadata headers with the same name are submitted for a resource, the Blob service returns status code 400 (Bad Request).
trans-unit.target: If two or more metadata headers with the same name are submitted for a resource, the Blob service returns status code 400 (Bad Request).

trans-unit.source: Resource URI Syntax
trans-unit.target: Resource URI Syntax

trans-unit.source: Each resource has a corresponding base URI, which refers to the resource itself.
trans-unit.target: Each resource has a corresponding base URI, which refers to the resource itself.

trans-unit.source: For the storage account, the base URI includes the name of the account only:
trans-unit.target: For the storage account, the base URI includes the name of the account only:

trans-unit.source: For a container, the base URI includes the name of the account and the name of the container:
trans-unit.target: For a container, the base URI includes the name of the account and the name of the container:

trans-unit.source: For a blob, the base URI includes the name of the account, the name of the container, and the name of the blob:
trans-unit.target: For a blob, the base URI includes the name of the account, the name of the container, and the name of the blob:

trans-unit.source: A storage account may have a root container, a default container that can be omitted from the URI.
trans-unit.target: A storage account may have a root container, a default container that can be omitted from the URI.

trans-unit.source: A blob in the root container can be referenced without naming the container, or the root container can be explicitly referenced by its name (<codeInline>$root</codeInline>).
trans-unit.target: A blob in the root container can be referenced without naming the container, or the root container can be explicitly referenced by its name (<codeInline>$root</codeInline>).

trans-unit.source: See <link xlink:href="6ec9ec4e-1758-4515-92b4-a85d4f27cf05" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Working with the Root Container</link> for more information.
trans-unit.target: See <link xlink:href="6ec9ec4e-1758-4515-92b4-a85d4f27cf05" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Working with the Root Container</link> for more information.

trans-unit.source: The following URIs both refer to a blob in the root container:
trans-unit.target: The following URIs both refer to a blob in the root container:

trans-unit.source: Blob Snapshots
trans-unit.target: Blob Snapshots

trans-unit.source: A snapshot is a read-only version of a blob stored as it was at the time the snapshot was created.
trans-unit.target: A snapshot is a read-only version of a blob stored as it was at the time the snapshot was created.

trans-unit.source: You can use snapshots to create a backup or checkpoint of a blob.
trans-unit.target: You can use snapshots to create a backup or checkpoint of a blob.

trans-unit.source: A snapshot blob name includes the base blob URI plus a date-time value that indicates when the snapshot was created.
trans-unit.target: A snapshot blob name includes the base blob URI plus a date-time value that indicates when the snapshot was created.

trans-unit.source: For example, assume that a blob has the following URI:
trans-unit.target: For example, assume that a blob has the following URI:

trans-unit.source: The URI for a snapshot of that blob is formed as follows:
trans-unit.target: The URI for a snapshot of that blob is formed as follows:

trans-unit.source: The .NET client library can list snapshots as <codeEntityReference>T:Microsoft.WindowsAzure.StorageClient.CloudBlob</codeEntityReference> objects when you call <codeEntityReference>M:Microsoft.WindowsAzure.StorageClient.CloudBlobContainer.ListBlobs(Microsoft.WindowsAzure.StorageClient.BlobRequestOptions)</codeEntityReference> with <codeEntityReference>P:Microsoft.WindowsAzure.StorageClient.BlobRequestOptions.BlobListingDetails</codeEntityReference> set to <codeEntityReference>F:Microsoft.WindowsAzure.StorageClient.BlobListingDetails.Snapshots</codeEntityReference>.
trans-unit.target: The .NET client library can list snapshots as <codeEntityReference>T:Microsoft.WindowsAzure.StorageClient.CloudBlob</codeEntityReference> objects when you call <codeEntityReference>M:Microsoft.WindowsAzure.StorageClient.CloudBlobContainer.ListBlobs(Microsoft.WindowsAzure.StorageClient.BlobRequestOptions)</codeEntityReference> with <codeEntityReference>P:Microsoft.WindowsAzure.StorageClient.BlobRequestOptions.BlobListingDetails</codeEntityReference> set to <codeEntityReference>F:Microsoft.WindowsAzure.StorageClient.BlobListingDetails.Snapshots</codeEntityReference>.
